title: Ugali with Sukuma Wiki
summary: A staple Kenyan dish made from maize flour, served with collard greens in a tomato-based sauce.
instructions: For Ugali: Bring 3 cups of water to boil in a heavy-bottomed saucepan.
In a separate bowl, mix maize flour with 1 cup cold water to make a smooth paste.
Add the paste to boiling water, stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
Reduce heat and continue stirring until the mixture thickens (about 10 minutes).
Cover and let it cook on low heat for 15 minutes, then shape into a round mound.
For Sukuma Wiki: Heat oil in a pan and saut√© onions until translucent.
Add garlic, tomatoes, and spices, cook until tomatoes soften.
Add chopped collard greens and a little water, then cover to steam for 5-7 minutes.
Season with salt and serve hot with ugali.

title: Nyama Choma
summary: Kenya's famous grilled meat, typically goat or beef, marinated in a simple spice rub and grilled to perfection.
ingredients: 1 kg goat meat (or beef), cut into chunks
instructions: In a large bowl, mix lemon juice, garlic, ginger, paprika, cayenne, salt, and pepper.
Add meat to the marinade, ensuring all pieces are well coated. Cover and refrigerate for at least 2 hours, preferably overnight.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat.
Thread meat onto skewers if using smaller pieces.
Grill meat for about 20-25 minutes, turning occasionally, until well-browned and cooked through.
Let it rest for 5 minutes before serving.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with kachumbari (tomato and onion salad) and ugali.

title: Chapati
summary: Soft, flaky flatbread that's a staple in Kenyan cuisine, perfect for scooping up stews and vegetables.
ingredients: 1/2 cup ghee or vegetable oil (for cooking)
instructions: In a large bowl, mix flour, salt, and sugar.
Add 2 tbsp oil and mix to make the dough soft.
Gradually add warm water, kneading to form a soft, elastic dough (about 10 minutes).
Coat dough with remaining oil, cover with a damp cloth, and let rest for 30 minutes.
Divide dough into 8 equal balls and roll each into a thin circle.
Heat a flat pan over medium heat and brush with ghee or oil.
Cook each chapati for about 1-2 minutes on each side, pressing down with a spatula until golden brown spots appear.
Brush with more ghee or oil while cooking for extra flakiness.
Keep cooked chapatis covered with a clean cloth to keep them soft.
Serve warm with your favorite stew or curry.
